results.title: Acid
results.brief_description: Presents varying ideas about LSD as expressed by users, former users, scientists and experts. Considers the extensive research now in progress, the recent discoveries about the physiological and psychological effects, and possible therapeutic uses. Psychedelic slides by Don Snyder. Song “Acid” written by Art Ciocco, performed and arranged by Tony Luisi.

results.title: Achieving sexual maturity
results.creator_credit: Ben Norman, FilmFair Communications and John Wiley and Sons
results.brief_description: The film deals with the sexual anatomy, physiology and behaviour of both sexes from conception to adulthood. It uses explicit live photography of nude males and females to explain external sexual anatomy - and graphics and diagrams for internal anatomy. It moves, in order through conception embryonic development, early childhood puberty, adolescence and adulthood. The film describes ovulation and menstruation in girls, ejaculation in boys and treats masturbation as a normal sexual activity in both sexes. At appropriate times through out the film, young people express spontaneous feelings and tell of individual experiences.

results.title: Achievement
results.creator_credit: Jean Halliday, Lex Halliday, Australian Instructional Films and Crusader Cloth Pty Ltd
results.brief_description: The story of the Australian wool industry. The success of this industry and its importance to the Australian economy is dependent on the work of many people; the sheep breedere, the boundary rider, the wool classer, the broker, and the skilled operatives converting fibre to cloth, all play their part.

results.title: Achieve with honor
results.brief_description: Sponsored by the Helms Athletic Foundation, this film gives a history of the Olympic Games, from the first Olympiad of the modern era at Athens in 1896 until the 11th Olympiad in Berlin in 1936. Presents and reiterates the notion that winning is less important than competing well but then, however, goes on to recount a list of victorious athletes from past Olympics. Narrated by Bill Henry.

results.title: According to specification?
results.creator_credit: Phil Dennis, Denis Ward, British Productivity Council and Technical and Scientific Films
results.brief_description: The problem of maintaining a consistent quality standard in manufactured products is discussed by a Production Director and a Sales Director. Conventional methods of inspection between processes and again of the final product prove too costly, and it is decided that quality control should become part of the manufacturing process. The practical, theoretical and statistical aspects of quality control are fully developed.

results.title: Accomplished women
results.creator_credit: Jerry Kramer, Charles Braverman and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description: Six women, including Helen Reddy, who have made it to the top in their chosen fields discuss a wide range of topics from politics to personal feelings. Highlights changing attitudes of women about themselves. The other women include Shirley Chisholm (Member of the US Congress), La Donna Harris (Founder - Americans for Indian Opportunity), Katherine Graham (Business woman - Washington Post), Nikki Giovanni (Poet), Virginia Apgar (Pediatrics specialist).

results.title: Accidents will happen
results.creator_credit: Guy Richards, Fabienne Nicholas, Cinemedia and XYZ
results.brief_description: In an attempt to pay his son’s medical bills following an unfortunate accident, a father (Brett Swain) sends in handicam footage of Timmy’s mishap into the reality show, “Accidents will happen”. His wife (Anni Finsterer) is bitterly disappointed, but makes the journey into the studio with the family when they are in contention for a financial benefit. When the production crew discover the faux accident has resulted in Timmy becoming wheelchair bound, they send down an executive (Chris Haywood) to reneg the claim and all appears to be lost. A timely tale about reality television that featured as part of the St Kilda Film Festival and Touring Film Festival, 1999. Cast also includes Michael Barrallon, Emily Barr, Alan Dale and Tania Lacy.

results.title: Accessible city doctor Wilfred Owen
results.brief_description: Cities are growing at a calamitous pace and they will be unliveable unless the idea of accidental growth is abandoned in favour of planning. Dr. Wilfred Owen discusses some of the features essential to the functioning of a city for business by day and recreation by night, and the role of transportation in effecting the growth of cities for the benefit of people

results.title: Access: experiment in Port Adelaide
results.brief_description: Patterned on the Canadian “Challenge for Change” experiments, this is an example of the video access concept at work for the Department of Social Security, helping to cut down the often mythical barriers between citizens and Government Departments involved in social welfare. No other credits available.

results.title: Access Video 1973-1982
results.creator_credit: Helen Eisler and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
This is a retrospective look at Access Video, an
independent public broadcasting project, using archival
footage shot over a period of nine years Australia wide.The images encapsulate Australian life on a social,
political and cultural level providing a historical glimpse
of the developing community and political activity during
the seventies whilst also illustrating the growth and
maturing of independent video within Australia. NB: Some
footage is of poor quality both in sound and image.
